title: In Nazi Germany, are German officers and commanders allowed to write journals and diaries? If not, what happens to them? - Quora

response.answer_text: Many individuals, both military and civilians, kept diaries during the Third Reich. Nazi Germany never had a proscription on personal journals, and even if it had, enforcing such a thing, even in a totalitarian state, would have been next to impossible. A great deal of what we know of the intimacies of life in those years is actually due to surviving journals and diaries. But there certainly were risks involved in placing your thoughts and opinions to paper, particularly if you were critical of the regime or the war, and there was always the risk that your journal would be discovered. For civilians, this included the very real risk that your home could be bombed out and your personal papers and journals would be discovered in the rubble. Somewhat less likely was the possibility of your home being searched by the Gestapo, but this risk increased exponentially if you happened to be Jewish. Victor Klemperer, a Dresden scholar and Jew, maintained a diary(published post-war as I Will Bear Witness)throughout the entire period of the Third Reich, and even wrote in it that if it were to be discovered, would most likely mean instant death for him. Eventually relegated to living in a Jewish ‘house’ that was regularly searched by the Gestapo, to mitigate the risk, he wrote only a few pages at a time and entrusted them to a gentile friend for safekeeping. As for the military, the difficulties of maintaining a journal, particularly in combat situations or close to the front, were naturally more considerable than if they were located further behind the lines. Ernst Jünger was a WWI veteran who had maintained a diary of the Great War years and had written a book, Storm of Steel, based on those diaries, which was published in 1920. A staunch militarist and nationalist who disapproved of the Weimar Republic, Jünger had strong authoritarian leanings but also resisted attempts by the Nazis to woo him to their side. When WWII broke out, Jünger eventually found himself an officer assigned to Wehrmacht headquarters in Paris. It was here that he maintained a diary of his war years, which was published in 1949 as Strahlungen(Radiations). Though often criticized as being a too distant, dispassionate observer, Jünger certainly understood the risks of writing ‘honestly’ in the Third Reich. Though not directly implicated, he was close to many of the officers involved in July 20th Plot against Hitler, and as a result of those ties, was summarily dismissed from the officer corps. Only a few months later, his son, while serving in a penal battalion as punishment for ‘subversive talk’ while a Kriegsmarine cadet, was killed in combat. Jünger wrote in his diary, “Often I have the impression that I am writing on paper that is already browning in the licks of the flames.” In spite of the risks, Jünger was also not afraid to write critically or disapprovingly of the regime or the military. Upon hearing of atrocities committed by SS units in Ukraine in 1941, Jünger writes, “I was seized by disgust in front of the uniforms, the shoulder boards, the medals, the weapons whose brilliance I had once so loved.” Had Jünger’s diaries been discovered, particularly after his dismissal from the Officer Corps following the July 20th 1944 Plot, he most certainly would’ve faced a fate far worse than a Strafbataillon(penal battalion). The fact that he was already a famous, published writer in the Third Reich(and a WWI hero to boot), would have counted little for him, and the Nazis might well have relished using him as an ‘example’ of what can happen to dissenters or critics of the regime, particularly at such a late stage in the war.

In all armies it is normal to have diaries and journals at all leves of hierarchy and serious such at above platoon level. If German or Allied company commander does not have his books in order there must be a proper explanation for it or legal action may follow. Cheers!
